title: Italy’s 5 Star Approves Coalition Government With Ex-Foes
text:
ROME—Members of Italy’s antiestablishment 5 Star Movement voted to form a coalition government with its former center-left Democratic Party foes, clearing the last major hurdle to new leadership.

The move heads off the risk of new elections and prolonged political instability after Matteo Salvini ’s anti-immigration League withdrew its support of government last month in a bid to force early elections that polls suggest it would have won. But even before the new government starts, questions over its longevity began to percolate, given the ideological and policy differences that divide its members.

Talks between the 5 Star and the Democratic Party to iron out differences have progressed since last week, when President Sergio Mattarella asked outgoing Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte to lead Italy’s next government.

Mr. Conte, a nonparty premier close to the 5 Star, resigned in late August after Mr. Salvini defected. But leaders of the 5 Star, which grew out of grass roots protest against Rome’s established politicians, decided to try for a new coalition with the Democrats, establishment bulwarks.

On Tuesday, the 5 Star also unveiled a draft of the policy program agreed with the Democrats. The 26-point agenda includes avoiding austerity measures that would hurt growth, introducing an economywide minimum wage, and boosting investments in renewable energy.

The past month’s political drama in Rome is a symptom of the growing disruption of European politics by insurgent movements such as the nativist League and the ideologically eclectic 5 Star Movement, while volatile electorates seek new answers to problems such as economic stagnation and poorly controlled immigration.

The 5 Star Movement, which advocates more use of direct democracy, periodically holds votes among its roughly 115,000 members about major decisions, using the party’s online platform, known as “Rousseau.” 5 Star leaders said they would have pulled out of talks with the Democrats if their members had rejected such a pact, leaving Mr. Mattarella little option but to dissolve Parliament and call early elections, likely in November.

“It’s been a landslide. I think we should all be proud that everybody waited for the decision” of 5 Star activists, said party leader Luigi Di Maio, referring to an online consultation in which 79% of nearly 80,000 votes supported the new government.

The pact’s approval will allow a new government to take office as soon as this week. The big question is whether such an awkward alliance of establishment and antiestablishment parties would last more than a few months.

The 5 Star Movement for years disparaged the Democrats, who as part of Italy’s governing coalitions between 2011 and 2018 dealt with the worst of Italy’s financial crisis. The 5 Star blamed the Democrats for many of Italy’s ills, while the Democrats in turn branded 5 Star leaders as amateurish and incompetent.

Italy’s long economic slump turned the 5 Star Movement into one of Europe’s strongest and loudest opponents of the continent’s economic orthodoxy, including the European Union’s strict rules on budget deficits, which have led to painful fiscal retrenchment in Italy and elsewhere. The 5 Star won the vote of one in three Italians in March 2018 national elections.

Allying with the Democrats is “a disavowal of their political discourse of recent years. The 5 Star was born as an ideological opposition to the Democratic Party,” said Franco Pavoncello, a political-science professor at Rome’s John Cabot University.

Although the two parties agree on some broad issues, such as defending the welfare state, helping Italy’s disadvantaged south and supporting small businesses, they also have major differences, including on infrastructure projects and immigration, said Daniele Albertazzi, a political scientist at the U.K.’s Birmingham University.

Italy’s draft budget for 2020, which the country must submit to the EU by Oct. 15, poses the first test for a new government. EU rules require Italy to show that it is reducing its high national debt. The 5 Star and Democrats have different instincts on how to proceed, with the former more open to running a larger deficit, and the latter more open to spending cuts.

Another hot issue will be immigration. During the 14 months that the 5 Star was in government with the League, it supported Mr. Salvini’s policy of closing Italian ports to ships carrying migrants rescued in the Mediterranean. The Democrats attacked that policy as inhumane and illegal.

“A large number of people who still support the 5S like what Salvini says about immigration and security. They don’t want to go back to opening the ports,” Mr. Albertazzi said. “It’s a big challenge because a lot of PD people want to show they are the opposite of Salvini.”

Write to Giovanni Legorano at giovanni.legorano@wsj.com
description: Italy’s antiestablishment 5 Star Movement voted to form a coalition government with its former center-left Democratic Party antagonists, clearing the last major hurdle to new leadership.
